trans-unit.source: Configure an ILB Listener for AlwaysOn Availability Groups in Azure
trans-unit.target: Configure an ILB Listener for AlwaysOn Availability Groups in Azure

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks you through steps of creating an AlwaysOn Availability Group Listener in Azure using an Internal Load Balancer (ILB).
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks you through steps of creating an AlwaysOn Availability Group Listener in Azure using an Internal Load Balancer (ILB).

trans-unit.source: Configure an ILB listener for AlwaysOn Availability Groups in Azure
trans-unit.target: Configure an ILB listener for AlwaysOn Availability Groups in Azure

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to configure a listener for an AlwaysOn Availability Group by using an Internal Load Balancer (ILB).
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to configure a listener for an AlwaysOn Availability Group by using an Internal Load Balancer (ILB).

trans-unit.source: Your Availability Group can contain replicas that are on-premises only, Azure only, or span both on-premises and Azure for hybrid configurations.
trans-unit.target: Your Availability Group can contain replicas that are on-premises only, Azure only, or span both on-premises and Azure for hybrid configurations.

trans-unit.source: Azure replicas can reside within the same region or across multiple regions using multiple virtual networks (VNets).
trans-unit.target: Azure replicas can reside within the same region or across multiple regions using multiple virtual networks (VNets).

trans-unit.source: The steps below assume you have already <link><linkText>configured an availability group</linkText><title></title></link> but have not configured a listener.
trans-unit.target: The steps below assume you have already <link><linkText>configured an availability group</linkText><title></title></link> but have not configured a listener.

trans-unit.source: Note the following limitations on the availability group listener in Azure using ILB:
trans-unit.target: Note the following limitations on the availability group listener in Azure using ILB:

trans-unit.source: The availability group listener is supported on Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, and Windows Server 2012 R2.
trans-unit.target: The availability group listener is supported on Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, and Windows Server 2012 R2.

trans-unit.source: The client application must reside on a different cloud service than the one that contains your availability group VMs.
trans-unit.target: The client application must reside on a different cloud service than the one that contains your availability group VMs.

trans-unit.source: Azure does not support direct server return with client and server in the same cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Azure does not support direct server return with client and server in the same cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Only one availability group listener is supported per cloud service because the listener is configured to either use the cloud service VIP address or the VIP address of the Internal Load Balancer.
trans-unit.target: Only one availability group listener is supported per cloud service because the listener is configured to either use the cloud service VIP address or the VIP address of the Internal Load Balancer.

trans-unit.source: Note that this limitation is still in effect although Azure now supports the creation of multiple VIP addresses in a given cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Note that this limitation is still in effect although Azure now supports the creation of multiple VIP addresses in a given cloud service.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial focuses on using PowerShell to create a listener for an Availability Group that includes Azure replicas.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial focuses on using PowerShell to create a listener for an Availability Group that includes Azure replicas.

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to configure listeners using SSMS or Transact-SQL, see <link><linkText>Create or Configure an Availability Group Listener</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to configure listeners using SSMS or Transact-SQL, see <link><linkText>Create or Configure an Availability Group Listener</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Determine the accessibility of the Listener
trans-unit.target: Determine the accessibility of the Listener

trans-unit.source: This article focuses on creating a listener that uses an Internal Load Balancer (ILB).
trans-unit.target: This article focuses on creating a listener that uses an Internal Load Balancer (ILB).

trans-unit.source: If you need an public/external listener, see the version of this article that provides steps for setting up an <link><linkText>external listener</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: If you need an public/external listener, see the version of this article that provides steps for setting up an <link><linkText>external listener</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Create load-balanced VM endpoints with direct server return
trans-unit.target: Create load-balanced VM endpoints with direct server return

trans-unit.source: For ILB, you must first create the internal load balancer.
trans-unit.target: For ILB, you must first create the internal load balancer.

trans-unit.source: This is done in the script below.
trans-unit.target: This is done in the script below.

trans-unit.source: For ILB, you should assign a static IP address.
trans-unit.target: For ILB, you should assign a static IP address.

trans-unit.source: First, examine the current VNet configuration by running the following command:
trans-unit.target: First, examine the current VNet configuration by running the following command:

trans-unit.source: Note the Subnet name for the subnet that contains the VMs that host the replicas.
trans-unit.target: Note the Subnet name for the subnet that contains the VMs that host the replicas.

trans-unit.source: This will be used in the $SubnetName parameter in the script.
trans-unit.target: This will be used in the $SubnetName parameter in the script.

trans-unit.source: Then note the VirtualNetworkSite name and the starting AddressPrefix for the subnet that contains the VMs that host the replicas.
trans-unit.target: Then note the VirtualNetworkSite name and the starting AddressPrefix for the subnet that contains the VMs that host the replicas.

trans-unit.source: Look for an available IP Address by passing both values to the Test-AzureStaticVNetIP command and examining the AvailableAddresses.
trans-unit.target: Look for an available IP Address by passing both values to the Test-AzureStaticVNetIP command and examining the AvailableAddresses.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the VNet was named MyVNet and had a subnet address range that started at 172.16.0.128, the following command would list available addresses:
trans-unit.target: For example, if the VNet was named MyVNet and had a subnet address range that started at 172.16.0.128, the following command would list available addresses:

trans-unit.source: Choose one of the available addresses and use it in the $ILBStaticIP parameter of the following script.
trans-unit.target: Choose one of the available addresses and use it in the $ILBStaticIP parameter of the following script.

trans-unit.source: Copy the PowerShell script below into a text editor and set the variable values to suit your environment (note that defaults have been provided for some parameters).
trans-unit.target: Copy the PowerShell script below into a text editor and set the variable values to suit your environment (note that defaults have been provided for some parameters).

trans-unit.source: Note that existing deployments that use affinity groups cannot add ILB.
trans-unit.target: Note that existing deployments that use affinity groups cannot add ILB.

trans-unit.source: For more information on ILB requirements, see <link><linkText>Internal Load Balancer</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on ILB requirements, see <link><linkText>Internal Load Balancer</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Also, if your availability group spans Azure regions, you must run the script once in each datacenter for the cloud service and nodes that reside in that datacenter.
trans-unit.target: Also, if your availability group spans Azure regions, you must run the script once in each datacenter for the cloud service and nodes that reside in that datacenter.

trans-unit.source: Once you have set the variables, copy the script from the text editor into your Azure PowerShell session to run it.
trans-unit.target: Once you have set the variables, copy the script from the text editor into your Azure PowerShell session to run it.

trans-unit.source: If the prompt still shows >>, type ENTER again to make sure the script starts running.Note
trans-unit.target: If the prompt still shows >>, type ENTER again to make sure the script starts running.Note

trans-unit.source: The Azure Management Portal does not support the Internal Load Balancer at this time, so you will not see either the ILB or the endpoints in the portal.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Management Portal does not support the Internal Load Balancer at this time, so you will not see either the ILB or the endpoints in the portal.

trans-unit.source: However, Get-AzureEndpoint returns an internal IP address if the Load Balancer is running on it.
trans-unit.target: However, Get-AzureEndpoint returns an internal IP address if the Load Balancer is running on it.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, it returns null.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, it returns null.

trans-unit.source: Verify that KB2854082 is installed if necessary
trans-unit.target: Verify that KB2854082 is installed if necessary

trans-unit.source: Open the firewall ports in availability group nodes
trans-unit.target: Open the firewall ports in availability group nodes

trans-unit.source: Create the availability group listener
trans-unit.target: Create the availability group listener

trans-unit.source: For ILB, you must use the IP address of the Internal Load Balancer (ILB) created earlier.
trans-unit.target: For ILB, you must use the IP address of the Internal Load Balancer (ILB) created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Use the following script to obtain this IP Address in PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Use the following script to obtain this IP Address in PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: On one of the VMs, copy the PowerShell script below into a text editor and set the variables to the values you noted earlier.
trans-unit.target: On one of the VMs, copy the PowerShell script below into a text editor and set the variables to the values you noted earlier.

trans-unit.source: Once you have set the variables, open an elevated Windows PowerShell window, then copy the script from the text editor and paste into your Azure PowerShell session to run it.
trans-unit.target: Once you have set the variables, open an elevated Windows PowerShell window, then copy the script from the text editor and paste into your Azure PowerShell session to run it.

trans-unit.source: If the prompt still shows >>, type ENTER again to make sure the script starts running.
trans-unit.target: If the prompt still shows >>, type ENTER again to make sure the script starts running.

trans-unit.source: Repeat this on each VM.
trans-unit.target: Repeat this on each VM.

trans-unit.source: This script configures the IP Address resource with the IP address of the cloud service and sets other parameters like the probe port.
trans-unit.target: This script configures the IP Address resource with the IP address of the cloud service and sets other parameters like the probe port.

trans-unit.source: When the IP Address resource is brought online, it can then respond to the polling on the probe port from the load-balanced endpoint created earlier in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: When the IP Address resource is brought online, it can then respond to the polling on the probe port from the load-balanced endpoint created earlier in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Bring the listener online
trans-unit.target: Bring the listener online

trans-unit.target: Follow-up items

trans-unit.source: Test the availability group listener (within the same VNet)
trans-unit.target: Test the availability group listener (within the same VNet)
